projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

2009-07 Lauren ProuxText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p: HOLY CHVRCHES Complaint, for her childrens diſobedience.

q.l: HE which the Church, for Mother will not haue,
And ſtill continues in his ſtubborne will,
May be aſſurde, that God him wil not ſaue,
But let him head-long runne, from worſe, to ill:
If thou for euer then, with him wilt bee,
Come home againe, the Keys he left with mee.

lg.l: VVHiles Adam ſoundly ſléep did take,
A louing Spouſe to be his make,
So Chriſt our Lord vpon the roode,
By death on ſléepe did fall:
And from his ſide water and blood
Did runne to rinſe vs all.
Whereby his Church he did ordaine
The cauſe why all that bitter paine
And cleanſed her from filthy crime
And wanne her ſtrait from time to time,
Or elſe, as heathen men to be,
Wherefore (O man) take thou good keep
Vnto all ſuch like wandring ſhéepe
O erring flocke, with all thy powre,
Or helliſh wolfes will thée deuoure,
You ſhould be children of Gods houſe,
Gods holy Church, and louing Spouſe,
Aug. in pſa. 88. & de lymb. lib. 4. Cip. c. 10. de ſimplicitate prelat. Prouerb. 1.9. Iohn 14.16, 26. Iohn 15.26. Iohn 16.7.As holy Doctors all write this,
To whom Chriſts Church no mother is,
To me his Spouſe to ſend:
That in all truth I might be led,
The 2 Teſtamēts Malach. 2.7. Eſa. 12 3. Rom. 10.15. Iohn 10.From my two dugges the foode of life
Then ſhould you anſwer ſuch a one,
1. Cor. 11.16. 1. Reg. 15.22. 2. Cor. 10.5. 1. Pet. 1.14.No ſuch cuſtome haue we in this,
For we wel know, Obedience is
By me you know, God, and his word,
How do you thinke your ſinfull ſtate
O thinke on what our Sauiour deare
The ſpace of thrée and thirty yeare,
And poorely borne, it is wel knowne,
Thou needſt not to be tolde:
To bring thée to his folde.
With loue long hath thee ſought:
The poereleſſe price who can expreſſe
For loue of thée his griefe was great,
From his ſwéete face a bloudy ſweate,
Marke how his bleſſed fleſh was rent,
Yet for thy ſake he was content
Vpon his head, him to diſgrace,
They ſet a crowne of thorne:
That ſtreams of bloud ranne downe apace,
His bleſſed hands and féete thereto
Three houres ſo, moſt bitter woe
For thee thy Lord did taſte.
His head with thorns, his eies with tears,
His mouth is filld with gall:
This heauenly bridegroome on the Roode
His Church to Spouſe did take:
And others all as baſtards broode
Then all his paine it is in vaine,
Except in me thou wilt remaine
Galat 7. 1 Pet 3 21. Ephet. 5.24.As well Noes Arke did ſignifie,
When all the world was drownd:
Symbol. Athan. Iohn 15.1.5, & 6Séeke where thou wilt, no other place
From ſinne can ſet thée frée:
Of all the treaſures of his grace
The Keyes he left with me.
My Spouſe aſcending left with me,
That I might giue, as cauſe I ſée,
The ſeauen ſacraments.Giue eare to me a little ſpace,
How ſeauen conduits of God's grace,
And firſt in Baptiſme I do beare
The ſacrament of Baptiſme.(Through God the holy ghoſt)
Moſt faithfull children farre and neare
Then do I ſtrengthen them alſo,
To fight againſt their deadly foe,
If they, through ſinne, and Satans guile
I can them ſalue and reconcile,
I féede them all with Angels foode,
And heauenly Manna pure:The holy Euchariſt.
Which hung for them vpon the Roode
I giue them grace to multiply,
Vnder whoſe charge my children liue,
Should children borne ſtill placed be
When languiſhing ſore ſicke they lie
To comfort them my Paſtors hie,
In that moſt dreadfull gate.The ſacrament of extreame Vnction.
The gate that all mankinde muſt goe,
With holy oyle againſt their foe,Iacob. 5.14.
Moreouer this,The holy ſacrifice of the maſſe. I haue a pure
Which to my children doth procure
Vnto the ſetting of the ſame
With other giftes and graces moe,Eccl. 24.
Which all that thus vnkindely goe
From me, of force muſt loſe.
I groane, I ſigh, I ſobbe and ſéeke
To ſaue thée from hell fire.
Thy Fathers force, and potent hand
Luc. 10.16.If thou thy Mother doſt withſtand,
Eſai. 49, 23.How mighty Kings ſhall foſter me,
And Quéenes muſt giue me ſucke.
O how ſhould I forgotten be
Thus in ſo ſhort a ſpace:
For neuer ſince Chriſt planted me,
That I did hide my face.
Yet may the ſimpleſt plainely ſée
Yet ſpurning at the pricke, you know,
Full falſly they doe me accuſe
Matth. 13.25.Their owne darke cauſe to cleare:
That I Gods truth did cleane refuſe
Math. 28.20. Iohn 14.16.26 Iohn 15.26 Iohn 16.7.Though Chriſt my Spouſe, and only aide,
As is in Scripture plainely ſaide,
If that a Bird cannot inclineMath 10.20. Luc. 12.6.
If to each creature he doe yéelde
And to the Lillies of the field
And ſuffer ſo hell gates to win,Math. 16.18.
My feete are placed on the rocke,
My God is my defence:Gala. 15.1. Pſal. 17.31.
The force of all the helliſh flocke
Of Trueth I am the onely ground,1. Tim. 3.15.
In me Gods will is onely found,
In me all grace doth dwell.
Set in the Sunne to ſhine:
I am that citty on a hill,Math. 5.15.
Thats hid from no mans eine.
I am cut forth of Chriſt his ſide,
To fill the world both farre and wide,
Vnto that faith then firmely ſticke
By Dauids words I hold this plea,Pſal. 2.8. Pſal. • 1.8.
That Chriſt muſt rule and raigne:
From ſea to ſea, and from the ſea
How can they charge me that I ſhould
For, ſo his promiſe cannot holde,
He prayd for me moſt feruently,
And therefore did aſſure to me,
Luc. 22.31. Luc. 12.49. Math. 13.24, 30My faith ſhould neuer faile.
O you poore ſoules ſo purchaſed,
What fury hath ſo fondly led
Through wicked wealth, or worldly feare,
Leſſe to eſtéeme of God then golde,
O that ſuch ſenſuall pleaſure ſhould
Heb. 12.1 & 2. Math. 16.24. Math. 10.37, 38.If here thy croſſe thou wilt not take
Be ſure thou ſhalt it finde.
But if like Chriſts diſciple ſound,
In heauenly wealth thou ſhalt abound,
Alas, you runne your courſe in vaine,
Or elſe you néedes muſt drowne.
That we alwayes with her accord,
And ſo make vp, and end.
